entry.title: Harmonizing UI5 URLs: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN
entry.content:
What Do We Do?

To further enhance consistency and ease of access, we are now making the convenient URLs the new default for all Demo Kit  resources. The following table shows the previous URLs and their short an convenient URLs:

Previous URLs

Short and Convenient URLs

openui5nightly.hana.ondemand.com

sdk.openui5.org/nightly

openui5.hana.ondemand.com

sdk.openui5.org

sapui5.hana.ondemand.com

ui5.sap.com

This follows our initial announcement “Short and Powerful: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN”.

Why We’re Doing This

One URL for OpenUI5 and one for SAPUI5 improves search engine indexing and discoverability which will lead to better search results. It will simplify the access to our documentation and tools for developers and establishes consistent and future-proof domains which are independent from the platform they are served from.

What Will Happen?

To make the transition as easy as possible, we will gradually redirect users to the new URLs. Here’s what you can expect:

  • Demo Kit Resources (HTML pages) will be automatically redirected to the new URLs starting on:
    • OpenUI5: December 8th
    • SAPUI5: January 7th
  • Runtime Resources (everything else) will be redirected to the new URLs starting on:
    • OpenUI5: January 7th
    • SAPUI5: ~UI5con Germany 2026

These steps are designed to give everyone plenty of time to adjust to the new URLs and ensure a seamless experience.

What You Should Do Now

Make use of the short and convenient URLs now by...

  • ...updating your bookmarks to the Demo Kit to use the new domains
  • ...adopting your applications to bootstrap OpenUI5 or SAPUI5 from the new domains
  • ...sharing this update with your teams and communities to help us spreading this information (Hint: still the old netweaver.ondemand.com URLs are in use!!)

Although we redirect the existing URLs they are going to continue to work. Once the old URLs will be sunset, we’ll inform you early enough upfront.

Note: To bootstrap SAPUI5 in non-cloud scenarios please use the Standard Variant for Bootstrapping. See details on the difference in Docu: Bootstrapping from Content Delivery Network and in note 2943781.

Another note on Tracking Prevention when using these URLs: Please mind the respective information in "Browser and Platform Support" for SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 and note 3216225 on how to handle it.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA for Group Reporting - Using Variables and Functions in Rules for Automatic Postings
entry.content:
Introduction

Automating postings in SAP S/4HANA Group Reporting reduce manual effort and ensure accuracy in financial consolidation. With release 2508.2, you can now enhance your rules using variables, functions, and comparison operators. These features bring flexibility and precision to complex consolidation scenarios, making it easier to reflect real business conditions in your reporting.

 

What You Can Use in Value Calculation Formulas

Rules for automatic postings (you can find more details in this introduction blog) can include the following components in the value calculation formulas: 

  • Variables: Read amounts from data different from the source, such as margin rate from the partner unit or number of issued shares
  • Functions:  Evaluate and calculate values, such as Minimum, Average, or Balance
  • Comparison Operators: <, >, =<, =>, =

Scenarios

Here are some examples of how variables, functions, and comparison operators can automate postings:

  • Earnings per share: SOURCE (net income) / VARIABLE (number of issued shares) 
  • Percentage of direct ownership in the partner unit: 100 * SOURCE_QTY (number of owned shares) / VARIABLE (number of shares issued by the partner unit)
  • Inventory profit elimination using the margin rate, from the partner unit, for this material: SOURCE_GC (inventory) *  - 0.01 * VARIABLE (margin rate by material from the partner unit)
  • Non-controlling interest calculation for the net income: SOURCE_GC (net income) * (1 - (VARIABLE (group share %)))

 

Defining Variables

In the Manage Rules for Automatic Postings app, you define variables in the new Variables tab.

Each variable includes:

  • Selection: Defined in the Define Selections app
  • Measure: Local currency, transaction currency, group currency, or quantity
  • Period interval: periodic, year to date, etc.
    Here, you find the same options as for the source data definition in the posting rules.
  • Matching fields: Up to 5 fields used to search the variable data by matching their value with the source data. 

In the above example, the matching fields are defined to search the margin rate reported by the selling unit and by material that matches the source data (e.g. the inventory values reported by the buying unit, broken down by partner unit, and material).

 

Value Calculation Formula

When defining value calculation formulas, you can combine operators, variables, and functions.

 

Variables

  • Predefined variables:
    • SOURCE: all source measures (transaction currency, local currency, group currency, and quantity)
    • SOURCE_TC, SOURCE_LC, SOURCE_GC, SOURCE_QTY: specific measures
  • Custom variables: Defined in the Variables tab (active only)
  • Up to 6 variables can be used in one rule.

Functions

You can use the following functions:

  • Balance: Used when the value calculation defined for the posting lines use percentages.
    In this case it might be that the resulting posting is not balanced because of rounding differences. You can use the Balance function in one additional posting line to balance the posting. The parameter of this function is the maximum amount that the posting line can post.
  • First Not Null: Used to eliminate the inventory profit using the most precise margin rate.
    For example, you can define two variables (Margin rate by material number, Margin rate without material number) and define in the value calculation that the system must use the first variable that is not null using the     FIRSTNOTNULL function.
  • Multiple functions can be included or nested in the value calculation formula of posting lines.

Operators

You can use the comparison operators with the IF function to evaluate values, for example: IF (SOURCE > 0, VARIABLE1, SOURCE).

Examples of Functions and Variables in Value Calculations

Variables in the Log

When rules include variables in the value calculation formula, their values and names appear in additional columns, such as Variable 1, Variable 2.

In the example below, the rules calculates the direct ownership %. The number of owned shares (from the investor) is displayed in the Source Quantity column, and the number of issued shares (from the investee) is displayed in the Variable 1 column. The calculated direct ownership % is displayed in the Posted Quantity column.

More Information

  • Rules for Automatic Postings
  • How to Define Variables
  • Blog Introducing New Rules for Automatic Postings 

________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Special thanks to MareikeBaudewig for reviewing this blog!

entry.title: msg group Accelerates Innovation with SAP Joule for Developers
entry.content:
Introduction 

Artificial intelligence is reshaping enterprise development, and SAP Joule for Developers in ABAP is at the center of this transformation. msg group, a leading re-insurance and transformation provider, is harnessing ABAP AI capabilities to modernize development, improve efficiency, and deliver more value to customers. 

 

About msg group 

With 25 years of experience in SAP products as well as custom development, msg group specializes in delivering innovative SAP solutions that help businesses run better. As a trusted SAP gold partner, they focus on state-of-the-art solution development leveraging modern ABAP Cloud techniques. 

 

The Challenge 

msg group faced a familiar challenge: 

  • Maintaining and modernizing large, complex ABAP codebases. 
  • Reducing the time developers spend on repetitive coding tasks. 
  • Meeting project demands for faster innovation without sacrificing quality. 

Traditional approaches often required significant manual effort, slowing down project timelines and increasing costs. 

 

The Solution: Leveraging SAP Joule for Developers in ABAP capabilities 

To overcome these challenges, msg group integrated ABAP AI capabilities into their development workflows. With features such as: 

  • AI-assisted code explanation to accelerate analysis of legacy ABAP coding. 
  • Joule Chat capability to support classic ABAP developers on their journey towards modern ABAP Cloud development. 
  • Automated unit testing generation to enhance reliability and reduce errors. 

ABAP AI enabled their developers to work smarter, not harder, freeing up time to focus on delivering business-critical innovations. 

 

The Results 

By adopting ABAP AI, msg group achieved measurable improvements: 

  • 20% increase in speed during the analysis of legacy ABAP code. 
  • Significant time savings for the initial generation of unit tests for ABAP classes and core data services. 
  • Increased developer productivity, allowing teams to focus on critical tasks and support other projects. 

Overall, this meant faster delivery of solutions, reduced costs, and higher satisfaction among all stakeholders. 

Learn more about msg’s use case here. 

 

Partner Perspective 

“SAP Joule for Developers is an essential part of the modern ABAP Cloud developer’s toolbox. It accelerates development with practical, high-impact use cases while empowering developers to decide how and where to apply it. This approach enables us to deliver innovation faster than ever — without compromising the quality our customers trust.” 
— Sebastian Freilinger-Huber, Principal IT Consultant, msg group 

 

Looking Ahead 

Building on these early successes, msg group plans to expand ABAP AI adoption across all business areas and projects developed on SAP BTP ABAP Environment and S/4HANA Cloud (Public and Private Edition). With SAP’s continued investment in AI, msg group is well-positioned to drive ongoing innovation and customer value. 

SAP Joule for Developers now unlocks even more potential with the new Custom Code Migration capabilities. These features streamline the transformation of classic ABAP code for SAP S/4HANA, making it easier to analyze, adapt, and modernize custom code with built-in explanations and guidance. For partners like msg group, it significantly reduces the effort required to transition customers to S/4HANA Cloud — while maintaining quality and accelerating time to value. 

 

Learn More 

Want to dive deeper into capabilities and use cases?  

Learn more about SAP BTP ABAP environment and  SAP Joule for Developers to explore how AI capabilities in SAP Build, including ABAP Environment, can transform your development workflows.

entry.title: What is the best development pattern or architecture to follow in SAP CAP Node.js projects
entry.content:
I’m working on a growing SAP CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) project using Node.js, and the team wants to adopt a consistent development pattern or architecture to keep the codebase clean, maintainable, and scalable.

I’m familiar with general backend principles like SOLID, but I’m not sure how well they apply in CAP, since a lot of the database interaction is handled through CDS services, entities, and the framework’s built-in handlers.

So my question is:

What is the recommended architectural pattern for CAP Node.js development?
Should we try to follow something like SOLID, or are there CAP-specific or Node-oriented patterns that work better?

I’d appreciate guidance or examples on patterns such as:

  • Service / Handler separation
  • Domain-Driven Design (DDD)
  • Clean Architecture
  • Repository or Data Mapper patterns (and whether they make sense in CAP, since CDS services already abstract the DB)
  • Modularization strategies for large CAP projects
  • Any best practices from real CAP projects in production

If you have suggestions, examples, or official recommendations from SAP, that would be extremely helpful.

entry.title: Re: Enterprise Management bundle and scope countries deac...

Hi!

Once the Define Scope activity has been completed in the workspace, it is no longer possible to deselect the countries or bundles.

However, since the workspace has not been deployed yet, it is still possible to delete the workspace and restart the setup activities, this time excluding the unwanted bundle and countries.

Please refer to the following KBAs for further guidance:

  • 3381588 - How to delete the Workspace in SAP Central Business Configuration - SAP for Me
  • 3689937 - Not possible to delete Bundles in SAP Central Business Configuration - SAP for Me

Best Regards,

entry.title: Re: Tax code via price determination cannot be determined...
entry.content:
Hello @Diego26 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/34cef32f5486451aa0fe114aa26ea817/145f4770a9c94575a1d2da8f99c51c3d.html?locale=en-US

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/the-difference-between-tax-categories-ttx1-and-mwst/qaq-p/14068947

To summarise, based on the scenario you described and the details I derived from your attached screenshots, it seems you only maintained TTX1 for the US but did not do same for DE. This might explain why the system cannot derive the tax code and generates the WS533 error.

Here is what I suggest:

Use the Set Tax Rates-Purchasing app to make the correction.

Set Tax Rates and create the necessary entries. Even if your transaction is IC inbound in DE, the RITT uses TTX1 and not MWST. Ensure your material tax classification supports this tax type.

Then you need to maintain material tax classification for DE using the Manage Product Master Data App.

Choose your material or product, go to Sales Tab, then Tax. Ensure you maintain DE --> TTX1, Tax Classification should be 1. If DE is missing, first extend the product to the DE sales org. (In you screenshots you only showed US classifications but no DE classification).

Your pricing procedure screenshots seem correct, so you do not need to carry out any modification there. The issue is rather tax rate availability in DE.

These steps should now allow your pricing to find TTX1 for DE, system will also determine the correct tax code and the document should save without the error.

You may also find this Blog interesting: SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Determine Tax Code in Purchase Documents using Condition Technique

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: What is the minimum capacity units (CU) to activate Object Store in SAP Datasphere?
entry.content:
Hello,

last month I tested it and the costs are higher than keeping the data in RAM,

the CU related to RAM and Disk to keep the data in memory for a month are lower than CU consumed just to copy the data inside object store.

Just a copy of data with replication flow and the merge task (necessary as it is similar to a SQL "commit" statement), gives a cost, in terms of COMPUTE, higher than keeping the data in memory for a month. ( I do not imagine refreshing the data daily ).
The table i tested was 1.5 GB with 140Mi rows. 

Talking to a colleague that works on other platforms, the problem seems related to the spark cluster and applications that are "way oversized". => I do not imagine the costs for smaller tables.

I tested transformation flows and filters / partitions do not influence costs, it costs less in term of compute to reload the entire dataset rather than working with portion of the source (even with partition).

Then there are issues only solved in US tenants (where all the demo come from),

for example we are unable to run optimize / vacuum / merge as they fail (a note says : open a ticket to apply the corrections).

Am I the only that tested it so far? is has been an year since Object store option is available.

entry.title: Re: What is the minimum capacity units (CU) to activate Object Store in SAP Datasphere?
entry.content:
I add this: problems seems related to the complexity of the underlying architecture,

as the data lake commands are issued by HANA Cloud via stored procedures (with language PYSPARK that is not documented in HANA Cloud HELP, but used by Datasphere).

Local file tables seen by Datasphere space are not fully "delta table" as you think, they are SQL views in HANA Cloud database that do an UNION between an HANA column tables and a "delta table" in the object store read through a virtual table.
Sometimes we get transactional inconsistency or incorrecy numbers from table monitor, but I can not dig deeper into it as we have not access to the embedded object store (X.509 certificate based remote source).

entry.title: MRP3 Planning Strategy causing change of Production Order dates from Sales Order ATP
entry.content:
Hi,

In my current S/4HANA system, we're testing two different Planning Strategies in the Material Master MRP3 tab: ZR vs ZA. All this is in a MTO scenario, discrete manufacturing.

ZR has been traditionally working in the company, and the need of ZA comes from being able to cost against sales orders, instead of production orders.

The workflow is: a sales order is created --> each sales order item creates a production order for the final production operations --> at release, an outbound delivery is created against the sales order (enhancement).

The issue is that when using a material with ZA strategy, when I execute the sales order item availability check, the related production order scheduling is triggered, and the basic production order start/end dates are modified, even if the order is released. In our company, if an order is released, it is already in an external MES system, so for us it's unacceptable that the sales order modifies the dates blindly. This happens even if there's already an outbound delivery created for that sales order.

When we use the ZR strategy, the dates are also modified if the order is not released, which could be fine (but not ideal) as the order is not yet in the MES system. However, when released, the Sales Order ATP doesn't modify the production order dates anymore. We believe this is because the sales order item related with the production order is already in the outbound delivery. If we manually create a new SO item, a new production order is created. When released, the outbound delivery is not modified and if we now perform the SO ATP, it also modifies the dates in the order.

Before we implement any further enhancement, I'd like to know if this behavior is standard and if it could be modified via customizing. It'd be very much appreciated.

If required, I can provide some customizing settings.

Thanks a lot,

VP

entry.title: Using CAP = Custom Services for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM
entry.content:
In today’s digital landscape, businesses need flexibility to extend standard solutions with custom logic and services. SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 provides this capability through Custom Services, and the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) makes it easier to build and deploy these services on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

This blog walks you through 9 essential steps to create and integrate custom services for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM.

High Level Process flow for designing Custom Services

Step 1 :  Prepare CAP development to your Business Need

Based on the customer business requirements, you can design, develop the CAP service model.. 

Kindly refer Supported and Unsupported functionalities for Custom Services.

Step 2: Deploy to BTP

once the BTP deployment is successful, ensure your CAP Service is working fine with your credentials and test it out with CRUD methods are functional.

Step 3 : Create a Communication System

In SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM, create a communication system to connect with your CAP deployed service:

  • Navigate to Administrator → Communication Systems.
  • Add a new system and provide:
    • System ID
    • Host URL (your CAP service endpoint)
    • Authentication details (OAuth or Basic)

Step 4 : Create a Custom Services

You can create up to 30 custom services in total, with the following limits:

  • A maximum of 30 mashup-based custom services.
  • A maximum of 15 entity-based custom services.

Navigate to User Menu - Settings - All Settings - Extensibility - Custom Services

Step 5 : Prepare CAP File Conversion

Run the following command in (your IDE where CAP is developed) the CLI to convert it to JSON: 
cds -2 json <service.cds file path> >output.json
upload the json as shown in the UI

Step 6 : Upload a File Converted

Upload the file converted from above step and upload as shown in below screen

Step 7 : Configure Host with assigning Communication System

Link your CAP service endpoint with the communication system created earlier:

  • Go to Communication Arrangements in SAP Sales & Service Cloud.
  • Assign the communication system and specify the service URL.

Step 8 : Design the App

On the UI View screen, choose  (Create) available on the top-right corner of the screen.

Select the required UI view pattern for your custom service 

Step 9 : Assign the Business Role to the Custom Services

Finally, ensure proper authorization:

  • Navigate to Business Roles in SAP Sales & Service Cloud.
  • Assign your custom service to the relevant role so users can access it.

Search the custom services and assign the Business Role

Best Practices

  • Use OAuth 2.0 for secure communication.
  • Keep CAP services modular for easy maintenance.
  • Test locally before deploying to BTP.

SAP Help Documentation for Custom Services

Supported and Unsupported CAP Services to Custom Services for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2

entry.title: Re: MRP3 Planning Strategy causing change of Production O...
entry.content:
The rescheduling of released production orders by Sales Order ATP in S/4HANA is standard behavior influenced by ATP check instructions ('Recreate Receipt Elements') and scheduling horizon settings, which can be configured to control date changes even on released orders through specific configurations or enhancements, as detailed in SAP Help documentation:

help.sap.com-01 
help.sap.com-02
help.sap.com-03
SAP has Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs) that address the rescheduling behavior of production order dates during ATP checks:
  • KBA 2422602: Discusses scenarios where production order basic dates are not readjusted according to scheduled dates, which can lead to planning inconsistencies during ATP checks.
  • KBA 3590839: Addresses situations where production orders are not considered in MRP's rescheduling, which can affect ATP checks and order scheduling.

These KBAs provide insights and guidance on managing production order dates in relation to ATP checks.

entry.title: EWM Kit to Stock | V51VP – Item was not found – Process cancelled
entry.content:
Hi All,

I’ve recently set up Kit to Stock in embedded EWM (EWM-driven, no production order). The process itself works fine in EWM: I can create the VAS order, the outbound delivery for the kit components is generated, and the inbound delivery for the assembled kit is created as expected. Picking, packing and posting in EWM all behave correctly.

The problem starts when the outbound GI and inbound GR try to post back to S/4. Both queues get stuck in SMQ2 with the error: V51VP – Item was not found – Process cancelled.

After looking into this, I can see both deliveries do exist in S/4, but neither has a movement type assigned. Because of that, S/4 treats them as “no goods movement” documents, so the Handling Units coming from EWM can’t be packed into the S/4 deliveries. That mismatch triggers the error and prevents both the GI and GR from posting, which obviously leaves the stock quantities out of sync.

Standard Kit-to-Stock uses delivery types DOG (outbound) and DIG (inbound). In my system, both are being created correctly, but they arrive in S/4 without movement types, causing the sync failure. Has anyone else hit this issue with Kit to Stock using delivery types DOG/DIG? If so, how did you resolve the missing movement type assignment on the S/4 side?

Any help would be appreciated. Thanks

entry.title: Re: SAP OData Service URL Construction
entry.content: “Remote name could not be resolved” means a DNS / network issue, not an OData issue. Quick checks (SAP-confirmed): Verify the hostname resolves (ping / browser test). Test with IP instead of hostname. SAP Router strings do NOT work for OData/HTTP. Confirm ICM ports in SMICM (8000+inst or 44300+inst). If behind firewall, access must be via SAP Web Dispatcher. For BTP access, ensure SAP Cloud Connector mapping is correct. If the IP works but hostname doesn’t → DNS is missing.

entry.title: Re: Use Datastore to avoid too many duplicate MPL attachments in exception retries
entry.content:
Very high retries or unlimited retries gives us flexibility in two scenarios.

1.To automatically resend the failed messages when target connection is resolved without manual intervention. This scenario is encountered during weekend maintenance downtimes of the connected systems. The backed-up messages in Integration layer will start flowing without manual retry.

2.When we are waiting for a change/fix to move to production then it should automatically process the failed message when the new fix is promoted to Production.

Yes, moving message to a dead letter queue is another technique but we were focusing on automatic reprocessing of messages for temp connection issue like downtimes or when Interface requires a quick emergency fix.

entry.title: ONB_ Crossboarding triggering in both ONB1.0 and ONB2.0 for Internal Hires
entry.content:
Hi all,

We previously used ONB1.0 and have now moved to ONB2.0. We no longer want Crossboarding to trigger in ONB1.0, but when we initiate a transfer, it still triggers Crossboarding in both ONB1.0 and ONB2.0. How do we prevent a record from being created in ONB1.0?

We currently have three Crossboarding rules, and they work correctly for ONB2.0. However, ONB1.0 continues to generate a record:

  1. Rule linked to Business Configuration > Job Information > Trigger Rules > OnPostSave

  2. EVENT_TRANSFER

  3. ONB2_InternalHire_Configuration rule (scenario: Initiate Internal Recruit Configuration)

As per KBA 3515053, if no rule exists with the “Initiate Internal Recruit Configuration” scenario, the system assumes the condition is true and creates a Crossboarding 1.0 record. The KBA suggests creating a rule for ONB1.0 with a condition that can never be true.

However, my tests show:

  • When the Initiate Internal Recruit Configuration rule evaluates to true, a CXB record is created in both ONB1.0 and ONB2.0.

  • When I add an impossible condition (so rule evaluates to false), a record is created in ONB1.0 only, and nothing in ONB2.0.

How can we fully stop ONB1.0 from generating a record, but creates only in ONB2.0?


We still have some users completing CXB in ONB1.0, so deactivating the process may not be a practical solution for some more time. Also, the KBA mentions  as a symptom that "disabling the Process Filter and Crossboarding Process in Super Admin did not help", which adds to the confusion.

Please let me know how to just trigger CXB for ONB2.0.

Regards,

Divia

@Gopinath_Murugaiyan

entry.title: Application Decisions for Sales Order Management in CX - Part 1
entry.content:
Summary

One of the key functions within the sales process is the creation of a Sales Order, typically followed by its replication to the back-office system (whether SAP ERP or SAP S/4HANA). This process, known as Sales Order Management, is part of the Lead-to-Cash enterprise process and is a common scenario across multiple industries.

The Sales Order Management (Customer > Sales > Customer Order and Contract Management) encompasses the entire customer order lifecycle, from order creation to fulfillment orchestration. It includes activities such as determining competitive pricing, checking real-time inventory availability, managing customer credit risk, transferring customer demand to downstream logistics processes, and monitoring overall order-fulfillment status.

This process leverages several components across both front-office and back-office applications and, in some cases, integration tools. Potential applications supporting this business capability include SAP Cloud for Customer or SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, and SAP S/4HANA Sales, integrated with the respective back-office systems.

The purpose of this document is to provide key decision criteria to help you, and your organization determine how best to support these business requirements within your target architecture. Most of the information presented here is publicly available through SAP channels such as the SAP Help Portal; however, it has been consolidated here for your convenience into a single, comprehensive reference.

This document has two parts: The first focuses on the functional and business aspects, and the second covers the technical details. At the end of the technical section, you’ll find a conclusion that summarizes both parts.

Business Requirements

During the target solution definition, these are the business capabilities related to Sales Order Management mentioned in the Reference Business Architecture or RBA (part of the SAP Enterprise Architecture Framework):

  • Sales Order Management: Ability to cover the full cycle of customer order processing, from multichannel order creation to fulfillment orchestration. It includes determining a competitive price, checking online inventory availability, managing customer credit risk, handing over customer demand to logistical follow-up processes, and tracking overall order-fulfillment status.
  • Customer Order Monitoring: Ability to monitor the execution of customer orders by checking and analyzing key operation-performance indicators. This includes raising attention to business exceptions and potential defects, for proactive prevention.

Solution Options

In the customer experience domain, two options could cover the giving capabilities (not including a back-office system):

  • SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud: Sales Orders
  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2: Sales Orders

Note: Although SAP S/4HANA Sales manages sales orders lifecycle through its Order and Contract Management functionality, this document does not aim to describe or analyze those standard features.

Characterization of the Solution Options

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), is SAP's on-demand cloud-based Customer Relationship Management, it consists of SAP Cloud for Sales and SAP Cloud for Services.

Sales Orders

In SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), the sales process starts with maintaining a product catalog that includes pricing and discount details. Sales representatives create quotes for interested customers, reusing data from existing opportunities and adding cross-sell products as needed.

Quotes undergo pricing, either within C4C or through integration with the back-office, SAP ERP/SAP S/4HANA, can follow an approval workflow before being sent to the customer.

Quotes are also part of the process: Once a quote is accepted, a sales order is created directly in C4C or as a follow-up in the back-office. Orders are synchronized across systems, ensuring visibility of delivery, invoicing, and fulfillment through the 360° Customer View.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is considered the next evolution of SAP C4C - Sales. SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is designed to help sales teams manage their accounts, leads, opportunities, and activities. This version includes new features and improvements to help sales professionals improve their sales performance, streamline their processes, and provide better customer experiences.

Sales Orders

In SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, a Sales Order represents the agreement between the seller and customer regarding product delivery or service provision, including defined prices, quantities, and dates.

This flexibility allows organizations to handle both standalone and integrated sales order scenarios seamlessly.

Criteria to determine the most suitable target solution

Several aspects will determinate the best solution to handle Sales Orders in your architecture, here’s some of the most relevant ones related to the functional area:

1. Sales Order Types

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

C4C offers three different types of sales orders:

  • External and Internal: This is the default mode and allows sales order creation with bi-directional transfer of sales orders between SAP C4C and SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP. Example: A sales representative creates a sales order in SAP C4C while visiting a customer, the order is immediately replicated to SAP S/4HANA and updates from this system (such as delivery status, invoice number, or quantity changes), are sent back to C4C.
  • External Only: This mode supports Display Only of sales orders that are created in external system and displayed in the cloud solution. Example: A sales representative logs into SAP C4C and views an order that was created entirely in SAP S/4HANA by an e-commerce system.
  • Internal Only: This applies for the standalone scenario where these types of orders only exist within SAP C4C and do not support the price simulation or the use of back-office systems like SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP. The orders of this type can only be previewed, printed and sent by e-mail. Example: A sales representative creates a Sales Order that exists only in C4C and It cannot simulate prices.

Please refer to the SAP Help Portal Maintain Sales Order Document Types section for more details.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 enables users to manage and track all sales interactions related to orders vi the maintenance mode parameter as follows:

  • Internal & External: You can replicate sales orders and receive continuous updates on them from external SAP systems. You can create, replicate, and modify the sales orders with bidirectional data transfer between an external SAP system and SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.
  • External: You can replicate sales orders from external SAP systems, but cannot edit the sales orders in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. In SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, you can only display these sales orders, which are created in external systems.
  • Internal: You can create and edit sales orders only in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.

Visit the Configure Sales Orders section in the SAP Help Portal for more information.

2. Partner Determination

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

In C4C, you can configure the allowed involved parties at the sales order header and item level using determination rules and code list restrictions in the Determination of Involved Parties configuration. It is also possible to add parties manually as needed.

With the “Take Over Party Determination” function enabled, parties involved are copied or inherited from a predecessor document, for example, from a Sales Quote document, into the Sales Order.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 you can determine involved parties for business transactions using party roles and the connected determination rules and master data. 

For Sales Orders, you can configure all party role assignments in the “party schema“ that handles both, party roles that can be internal and external involved parties. The party role selection can be controlled through Code List Restrictions as well.

3. Pricing

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP C4C typically uses standard pricing logic that is integrated to reflect the ERP pricing conditions. The settings allow it to replicate such conditions through various middleware, ensuring consistency with the pricing data from SAP ERP systems.

SAP C4C provides flexible internal, external, and offline pricing and pricing discounts in Sales Orders:

  • Internal Pricing (not integrated with SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP): For this you must maintain price lists and customer-specific price lists, along with discount lists and a single pricing procedure in the system. Internal pricing takes prices from the price list created by your administrator and can include optional predefined discounts.
    Additional features in the internal pricing option:
  • Allows price adjustments including action “Update Pricing” in the Pricing tab in the Sales Order (this tab appears only in maintenance mode “Internal”).
  • Edit List Price and Product Discount (%) in the Products table.
  • Edit Overall Discount (%) in the Overview.
  • External Pricing: Allows you to retrieve their complete price information including tax details from an external SAP system like SAP ERP and SAP S/4HANA (keep in mind that your C4C system must be connected directly with the external system via a middleware).
    Pricing is obtained via a user action to retrieve the external pricing result and apply discounts or other price elements is the Sales Order if necessary.
    How external pricing is executed? External pricing is done through order simulation in the back-office system. The back-office system then simulates a complete document, and you receive the results in your quote or order.
  • Offline Pricing: In “offline mode”, you can calculate an estimated price value based on the price list existed in C4C (that could be synchronized from the back-office system), including a fixed or percentage-based discount for your Sales Order items created in offline.
    Sync the discount details when you are working online again. You can also view the external pricing result in offline mode.
    Extensibility: You can map extension fields created in your 'Z' space in SAP ERP with extension fields in your SAP C4C system and use them for offline pricing calculation.

More details available in the Create Sales Orders and Pricing sections of the SAP Help.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 builds upon advanced functionalities, providing more comprehensive and flexible pricing schemes, often leveraging enhanced analytical capabilities and AI-driven pricing strategies.

The solution offers two types of pricing:

  • Internal pricing (native pricing): The price is calculated using the pricing components and pricing master data defined in the system (not integrated with SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP).
  • External pricing: The complete price information including tax details is retrieved from an external SAP system. End-users request pricing via simulation in sales orders to retrieve the external pricing result and apply discounts or other pricing elements if necessary. You can also use the solution to determine credit limits and product availability information from simulation.

You can import pricing configurations from all SAP S/4HANA products to SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 through automated integration. You can manually download pricing configurations from SAP ECC and upload them to SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.

For more information please check the Pricing section in the SAP Help Portal.

4. Master Data

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP C4C integrates with SAP back-office systems to fetch relevant master data required during the creation and processing of sales orders.

Master data synchronization ensures that information such as customer preferences, product availability, and pricing remains up-to-date throughout the sales order lifecycle.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

It provides an improved data model for managing customer relationships, product configurations, and order processing details.

Utilizes integrated analytics and AI-driven insights to streamline the sales order process, optimizing customer engagement and fulfillment.

5. Approvals

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

In SAP C4C, you can set different approval processes for sales orders before submitting for processing. Multiple approval levels are available as defined in the configuration.

If a Sales Order needs approval, you can use a workflow action called “Submit Orders for Approval“ where you can: Revoke, Submit for Approval, Transfer, and Withdraw from Approval.

You can see the approval process, history, and details under the Approvals tab. Automatic approval is also possible and approvals via E-Mail.

More details available at the Complete Sales Orders in the available documentation.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

The solution supports Sales Order’s approval workflows that send a notification to the corresponding approver. Approval conditions can be based on amount or price.

In terms of transporting approval rule changes to a production environment, Sales Cloud V2 offers greater flexibility. You can transport an individual approval rule without needing to move the entire change project, and the solution also supports versioning.

If you need more information, please refer to the Submit Sales Orders for Approval section in the SAP Help Portal.

6. Mobile App

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP Cloud for Customer provides you with instant access to the solution data from a phone or tablet using the SAP Cloud for Customer Mobile Apps available for iPad, Android, and Windows Tablet.

Regarding the Sales Order processing, the Mobile App allows you to create and manage sales orders including:

  • Order Details
  • Line Items
  • Pricing
  • Fulfillment

In offline mode, several options are available including:

  • Product proposals
  • Promotions
  • Pricing (based on replicated conditions from ERP system)
  • Order validations like minimum order quantity

More information in the About Mobile Options section of the SAP help portal.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

The SAP Sales Cloud Mobile application provides you access to data in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 and allows your sales teams to:

  • View Sales Orders
  • Create and manage Sales Orders
  • Create External Sales Orders
  • Simulate Sales Orders

There's no offline support for this application at the moment, but in recent upgrades for the iOS app, it was mentioned the possibility to enable Downloads for Offline Access. However, downloaded entities like Sales Orders are read only and can't be modified.

More information in the SAP Sales Cloud Mobile Application and the Downloads documentation.

7. Machine Learning and Generative AI

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

At the moment there’s no Machine Learning or Gen AI functionalities in SAP C4C related to the Sales Order Management processes.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Sales Order Summary: A Gen AI feature that automatically analyzes and presents insights from pricing simulations including.

  • Change in product pricing from the original price, provides insights about whether the price has increased or decreased and by what percentage.
  • On-time delivery of the products, whether the products are scheduled for on-time delivery or if delivery is delayed.
  • Products within the order are substituted with an alternative product.
  • The number of free products, based on the pricing arrangement.

For more details, please refer to the Sales Order Summary documentation.

Conclusion

The first part of this document concludes here, providing a functional view of Sales Order Management within SAP Customer Experience’s cloud solutions.

In the next part, we will focus on the technical aspects, including integrations and extensibility options. This section will conclude with a comparison of the two available solutions: SAP Cloud for Customer (Sales Cloud) and SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Here’s the link for your convenience.

entry.title: The Secure Way to Migrate S/4HANA: Step-by-Step HANA Tenant Copy with SSL Encryption
entry.content:
As customers rapidly migrate S/4HANA systems to Private Cloud environments (Azure, AWS, GCP, SAP RISE), they often choose an "as-is" migration. This decouples functional upgrades from the technical move, significantly compressing project duration and minimizing the need for extensive regression testing.

While traditional methods like HANA Backup/Restore (only viable for small databases) and HANA System Replication (HSR) are common, HSR presents critical challenges in a cloud migration:

  1. Homogeneous Naming: HSR demands the same SID and Instance Number for source and target, which conflicts with new naming conventions often required on the cloud, especially in SAP RISE.
  2. Auxiliary Usage: Using the HA/DR focused HSR solution for a one-time copy complicates the reconfiguration of the target HA/DR setup after cutover.
  3. Cutover Time: Breaking replication and re-establishing HA/DR post-cutover adds additional downtime.

HANA Tenant Copy: The Migration Alternative

HANA Tenant Copy is an ECS-supported approach that addresses these HSR limitations. While operationally somewhat to HSR, it differs conceptually and is suitable for migrating systems that require a SID change on the target. It creates an isolated replica of any tenant, requiring mostly that the target HANA version is same or higher than the source.

🔐Securing the Tenant Copy Data Transfer (SSL)

A crucial security requirement is ensuring the data transfer between source and target is secure via SSL. Most Basis teams overlook this, thinking it requires external certificates. However, we can easily achieve this using the inbuilt certificate every HANA DB already possesses. In this post, we are going to see how we can 

Pre-Requisite –

Set-up below parameters on Source and Target Database. Also, log mode should be normal for Tenant Copy to work.

Verify the SYSTEM layer values of the following parameters in the global.ini file:

  • [communication] ssl must be set to systempki
  • [system_replication_communication] enable_ssl must be set to on

On Source DB only –

Verify the SYSTEM layer values of the following parameters in the global.ini file:

  • [communication] listeninterface must be set to .global

(A DB restart would be required in most cases).

When establishing connectivity between the Source and Target databases, the following port ranges should be opened. If security policies are restrictive, specific ports based on the instance number can be opened instead.

Port Range

Purpose

3XXXX

Mandatory. SQL port of the HANA Index Server. Main port used by application servers and SQL clients to connect to the HANA DB.

4XXXX

Mandatory. Internal HANA communication port, used heavily for system replication (HSR) and Tenant Copy.

5XXXX

Recommended. Used by nameserver, web dispatcher–related connections, and certain internal HA/scale-out services. Helps hosts exchange availability and topology information.

 Step-by-Step Secure Tenant Copy Execution

Step1: Create a dummy Tenant Database (ABC) on the source system to serve as a copy template. (Note: For actual migration, use the existing S/4HANA connected database, skipping this creation step.)

Take backup of the source database so that Tenant copy can be initiated (same restriction as that of HSR)

Step 2: On the target HANA system, create a Personal Security Environment (PSE) (e.g., TenantCopy) and assign its purpose as Database Replication.

Step 3: On the source HANA system, navigate to the $SECUDIR directory and copy the content of the root certificate, which is typically named clientpki_SYSTEMDB.cer. (Important: Use the SYSTEMDB certificate, not the tenant's certificate like clientpki_ABC.cer).

Step 4: Using the copied certificate content, create a new certificate entity within the target HANA database.

Step 5 : On the target system, execute the necessary SQL query to identify and note the certificate number assigned to the new certificate created in Step 4.

Step 6 : Add the certificate identified in Step 5 to the PSE created in Step 2 on the target system.

Step 7: Verify the successful addition by querying the PSE_CERTIFICATE view on the target HANA system.

Step 8: On the target system, create a Credential for the source database, using the Source SYSTEMDB password for authentication.

Step 9: On the Target, initiate the Replica Query to copy the source tenant (ABC) to the target tenant (XYZ). (In a real scenario, you would first stop the target Application Server, drop the existing S/4HANA target DB, and then create the new tenant with the exact required target name.).

Step 10 : Monitor the replication from the Target. Replication is active when the status shows Target_Active_Status = “Yes”. The replication is complete when the DB status in M_DATABASE changes to ACTIVE REPLICA, indicating the target is ready for finalization.

 

Step 11: On the target system, issue the Finalize Replica Query to bring the target database online. (Crucially, before executing the finalization, stop the source S/4HANA system to mark the business downtime start.)

After finalization, perform follow-up activities, including reconfiguring the HDBUSERSTORE and starting the target S/4HANA application system.

References –

Copying and Moving Tenant Databases | SAP Help Portal

Copy or Move Tenants Within System Replication | SAP Help Portal

 

Best Regards,

Javed Alam

SAP BASIS Technical Architect

entry.title: When duct tape isn't architecture: Why your SQL-based inventory workaround is holding you back
entry.content:
As enterprise architects, our job isn't just to set up systems. It's to build future-proof, resilient, and valuable IT landscapes. In retail today, the biggest challenge is creating a seamless omnichannel experience. Customers expect to see in-store availability online, get items ordered in-store delivered to their homes, and return products wherever it's most convenient for them.

But many of these initiatives fail because of a fundamental architectural flaw: scattered inventory data. In the past, this was often patched up with a workaround that just kind of... happened: a SQL Server-based "Central Inventory" database. It acted as a bridge to painstakingly sync inventory between two ERP systems and the e-shop. But what was once a necessary evil is now, in the age of SAP S/4HANA and SAP CAR, just technical debt that kills agility and sustainability.

The Foundation: POSDTA as the Single Source of Truth

The foundation for any successful omnichannel strategy is a single, reliable source of truth for all transactional data. This is exactly where SAP CAR's POS Data Transfer and Audit (POSDTA) module comes in. It's so much more than just a tool for collecting sales receipts. POSDTA is the central hub that consolidates, validates, and harmonizes sales and returns data from all channels in real-time—from the in-store cash register to mobile POS devices and the e-commerce backend.

From an architectural standpoint, we're not just fixing data inconsistencies; we're paying off technical debt. Replacing the old central inventory solution with a standardized process within our SAP landscape is also a move toward IT sustainability. We're cutting down on complexity, shutting down fragile interfaces, and reducing the energy and maintenance needed to run redundant systems.

The Game-Changer: OAA as the Brains and Sustainability Layer

Building on this solid foundation of real-time inventory data is Omnichannel Article Availability (OAA). OAA is the intelligence that turns raw data into promises you can keep to your customers.

Without the precise, centralized inventory info from POSDTA, OAA would be flying blind. But with this foundation, OAA can truly shine:

  1. Reliable Availability Info: OAA provides a real-time, accurate answer to the question, "Where is this item available?" and feeds that info to the webshop or customer app. The result: no more disappointed customers due to incorrect stock levels.
  2. Smart and Sustainable Sourcing: When an online order comes in, OAA uses configurable rules to decide the most efficient place to ship it from. This has a huge environmental and economic sustainability impact. Instead of shipping every item from a central warehouse across the country, OAA enables ship-from-store from the nearest location. This shortens delivery routes, cuts CO2 emissions, and makes better use of the stock you already have. It helps reduce overstock and subsequent markdowns—a direct win against waste.

The Bottom Line for Our Architecture Strategy

Choosing to centralize inventory in SAP CAR isn't just a technical migration. It's a forward-thinking architectural decision. We're replacing a reactive, makeshift solution with a robust, scalable foundation (POSDTA) that allows us to build valuable and sustainable services (OAA). We're investing in real-time capabilities, simplifying our IT landscape, and creating the agility that tomorrow's fashion business demands—all in an economically and environmentally responsible way.

entry.title: How to Spot Real Opportunities to Modernize During an SAP Migration
entry.content:
Every time a company prepares for an SAP migration, the same idea appears on the whiteboard. 

“This is the ideal moment to rethink the architecture.” 

It makes sense conceptually: 

You are already revisiting integrations, touching data, updating custom logic, revalidating processes, and reorganizing environments. On paper, it feels like a natural opportunity to fix old decisions and build a stronger foundation for the next decade. 

But in real life, migrations do not happen on paper. They happen inside organizations with limited bandwidth, tight deadlines, pressure to stay within support, and a long list of technical tasks that cannot slip. 

The truth is that modernization during an SAP migration is possible, but it only works under specific conditions. And knowing how to recognize those moments is what separates a smooth migration from one that collapses under its own ambition. 

This article walks through how to identify true modernization opportunities without transforming your migration into a second battle your team cannot afford. 

 1. Greenfield opens the door, Brownfield narrows it 

One of the clearest signals comes from the migration approach itself. 

A Greenfield migration naturally creates space for modernization. Starting fresh means you can adopt clean core, redesign integration patterns, remove historical complexity and rethink how the business should operate. Everything is already being rebuilt, so it makes sense to align the architecture to modern practices. 

Brownfield and Bluefield migrations are different. They carry history, decisions and technical debt. Many teams arrive at this point after twenty years of enhancements, quick fixes, interfaces built under pressure and custom logic created for business requirements that no longer exist. In these scenarios, trying to modernize everything at once becomes risky and expensive. 

This does not mean modernization is impossible in Brownfield. It simply means it must be selective and realistic. 

 2. Bandwidth determines the limits of modernization 

This was one of the strongest insights from practitioners. 
SAP migrations already stretch teams in every direction. 

People need to remediate data, rewrite custom logic to fit the new data model, validate thousands of test cases, redesign integrations, coordinate freeze periods, handle cutover planning and support simultaneous environments for months. 

If the organization does not explicitly provide more time, more people or more budget, modernization becomes impossible. Teams cannot fight two battles at the same time. 

A common mistake is assuming modernization will “fit naturally” inside existing migration tasks. It rarely does. If bandwidth is already consumed, modernization attempts create delays, testing failures and scope explosions. 

The best signal that modernization fits is simple. 
Leadership commits resources, not only expectations. 

 3. Look for overlap: modernization that complements migration work 

Even in high-pressure migrations, there are areas where modernization aligns perfectly with what the team must do anyway. These are the opportunities that experienced teams always look for. 

For example, when integrations must be revalidated, it becomes a natural moment to retire dead interfaces, remove duplicated endpoints or convert quick point-to-point connections into APIs. 

When master data is already being cleaned, it becomes easier to introduce governance rules and standard naming conventions. When reports need to be rebuilt, it creates the perfect window to simplify the pipeline or remove outdated transformations. 

These improvements don’t create a separate project within the migration. They sit on top of what the team is already doing, and they reduce risk instead of adding to it 

 4. Evaluate the real pain of legacy architecture 

The strongest indicator is the level of pain the current architecture is creating. 

If legacy integrations block new requirements, if custom objects break frequently, if reporting pipelines require constant maintenance or if data quality issues multiply every year, delaying modernization will only increase the cost. 

In those cases, the migration becomes a natural trigger. It is not just a modernization opportunity. It becomes a modernization obligation. 

On the other hand, if the architecture works well, even if it is not perfect, forcing a redesign during a migration can create unnecessary instability. 

The right moment is when the cost of doing nothing exceeds the effort of doing something. 

 5. Use migration to prepare modernization, not to overload the project 

During migration, focus on simplifying, cleaning and standardizing the areas the project already touches. After go-live, launch a dedicated modernization phase with its own scope, timeline and budget. 

This approach keeps the migration stable and predictable, while still creating the foundation for deeper improvements. 

Companies that follow this model often report smoother go-lives and faster modernization later, because the heavy work of cleaning and reorganizing was already done during the migration. 

The bottom line 

SAP migrations can absolutely create opportunities to modernize architecture. 
But the opportunity is not automatic. It appears only when certain conditions align. 

  • Greenfield makes modernization easier.  
  •  Brownfield requires discipline and realism.  
  •  Bandwidth defines the limits. 
  •  Overlap with existing tasks creates safe wins. 
  •  And the pain of legacy architecture determines urgency. 

The best modernization moments are the ones that come naturally from the migration itself. The best long-term transformations happen once the system is live and stable. 

Knowing how to distinguish both is what makes an SAP migration successful.

entry.title: How to Enhance Sales Order Item Processing in SAP: Tabstrip UI + Popup Quantity Editing
entry.content:
Building a Module Pool Program with Tab Strip, Popup Dialog, and Quantity Update in SAP ABAP 

Introduction 

In this post, we will look at how to build an SAP ABAP Module Pool application that displays Sales Order item details, opens a popup for editing quantities, and updates the values back to the main screen. 

 This requirement is common in logistics applications where users need to review and adjust quantities before posting follow-up processes. 

Business Requirement: 

  1. Display Sales Order Item Details using Tab Strip. 
  2. Provide two buttons: ADD SA and CANCEL. 
  3. On ADD SA → show popup with first 5 items. 
  4. Quantity is editable. 
  5. Popup has OK and CANCEL. 
  6. OK updates quantity back in main table. 
  7. CANCEL closes popup without change. 

 Technical Components: 

- Module Pool 

- Screens 0100 and 0200 

- Table Controls 

- Tab Strip 

- PBO & PAI modules 

- PF-STATUS 

- Internal tables 

Screen Designs 

Screen 100 – Main Screen 

Sales Order input field 

Tab Strip containing VBAP fields: 

  • POSNR 
  • MATNR 
  • CHARG 
  • ARKTX 
  • KWMENG 
  • WERKS, etc. 

Table Control (TABLE1) 

Buttons: 

GET 

ADD SA 

CANCEL 

Screen 200 – Popup Screen 

Modal popup 

Table Control (TABLE2) with: 

5 items only 

Editable Qty (KWMENG) 

Buttons: 

OK 

CANCEL 

Application Flow 

1️ User enters Sales Order number 

2️ Presses “GET” 

→ VBAP data retrieved 

→ Items appear on main screen 

3️ User clicks “ADD SA” 

→ Popup opens 

→ User edits quantity 

4️ User clicks “OK” 

→ Updated values transferred back 

→ Main screen refreshed 

5️ User clicks “CANCEL” 

→ Popup closes without changes 

Key ABAP Logic Implementation 

  1. Reading Sales Order Item Data 
SELECT vbeln posnr matnr charg arktx 

       kwmeng werks lgort vstel 

  FROM vbap 
  INTO TABLE lt_vbap 
  WHERE vbeln = gv_vbeln.

2. Passing First 5 Items to Popup 

lt_vbap1 = lt_vbap. 

DELETE lt_vbap1 FROM 6. "Keep only first 5 items

3.Updating Quantities Back in Main Screen 

LOOP AT lt_vbap1 INTO ls_vbap1. 

  READ TABLE lt_vbap INTO ls_vbap WITH KEY posnr = ls_vbap1-posnr. 

  IF sy-subrc = 0. 

    ls_vbap-kwmeng = ls_vbap1-kwmeng. 

    MODIFY lt_vbap FROM ls_vbap INDEX sy-tabix. 

  ENDIF. 

ENDLOOP.

4.Handling Table Control Updates 

MODULE read_data INPUT. 

  MODIFY lt_vbap1 FROM ls_vbap1 INDEX table2-current_line. 

ENDMODULE.

 Conclusion 

This Module Pool program demonstrates: 

Effective use of classic SAP GUI dialog programming 

Leveraging Table Controls and Popup Screens 

Clean user-driven quantity update process 

Practical design for logistics screens 

This module pool program demonstrates flexible SAP GUI programming using popups, table controls, and classic PAI/PBO logic. 

REPORT ZSALESITEM_DATA_TASK. 
 
TABLES:VBAP. 
 
TYPES:BEGIN OF TY R _VBAP, 
     VBELN TYPE VBAP-VBELN, 
     POSNR TYPE VBAP-POSNR, 
     MATNR TYPE VBAP-MATNR, 
     CHARG TYPE VBAP-CHARG, 
     ARKTX TYPE VBAP-ARKTX, 
     KWMENG TYPE VBAP-KWMENG, 
     WERKS TYPE VBAP-WERKS, 
     LGORT TYPE VBAP-LGORT, 
     VSTEL TYPE VBAP-VSTEL, 
 END OF TY_VBAP. 
 
 
DATA: LT_VBAP TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_VBAP, 
     LS_VBAP TYPE ty_VBAP, 
 
     LT_VBAP1 TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF TY_VBAP, 
     LS_VBAP1 TYPE TY_VBAP. 
 
CONTROLS: TABLE1 TYPE TABLEVIEW USING SCREEN 0100. 
CONTROLS: TABLE2 TYPE TABLEVIEW USING SCREEN 0200. 
 
START-OF-SELECTION. 
CALL SCREEN 100. 
call screen 200. 
 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*&      Module  USER_COMMAND_0100  INPUT 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*       text 
*----------------------------------------------------------------------* 
MODULE user_command_0100 INPUT. 
 
 CASE SY-UCOMM. 
   WHEN 'GET'. 
data LV_VBELN type vbap-vbeln. 
     SELECT POSNR MATNR 
            CHARG ARKTX 
            KWMENG WERKS 
            LGORT VSTEL  FROM VBAP INTO  CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF TABLE LT_VBAP 
      WHERE VBELN = LV_VBELN. 
   SORT lt_vbap BY vbeln. 
     WHEN 'EXIT'. 
       LEAVE PROGRAM. 
 
*      // Pop up 
   WHEN 'ADD'. 
     CALL SCREEN 200 STARTING AT 10 5 
     ENDING AT 100 10. 
 
 
 ENDCASE. 
 
ENDMODULE. 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*&      Module  STATUS_0200  OUTPUT 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*       text 
*----------------------------------------------------------------------* 
MODULE status_0200 OUTPUT. 
 SET PF-STATUS 'STATUS'. 
  CASE sy-ucomm. 
     WHEN 'ENTER'. 
     CALL  SCREEN 100. 
   WHEN 'CANCEL'. 
     CALL SCREEN 100. 
 
*  SET TITLEBAR 'xxx'. 
 ENDCASE. 
 
ENDMODULE. 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*&      Module  USER_COMMAND_0200  INPUT 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*       text 
*----------------------------------------------------------------------* 
MODULE user_command_0200 INPUT. 
 CASE sy-ucomm. 
 WHEN 'ENTER'. 
LOOP AT lt_vbap INTO ls_vbap ." where posnr = lv_posnr.  "kwmeng <> ls_vbap-kwmeng. 
       DATA(lv_index) = sy-tabix. 
 
   LOOP AT lt_vbap1 INTO ls_vbap1  where posnr = ls_vbap-posnr. 
         if sy-subrc = 0. 
         ls_vbap-KWMENG = ls_vbap1-kwmeng. 
         MODIFY lt_vbap FROM ls_vbap INDEX lv_index  TRANSPORTING KWMENG. 
       ENDIF. 
     ENDLOOP. 
     ENDLOOP. 
     LEAVE to SCREEN 0. 
 
   WHEN 'EXIT'. 
     LEAVE PROGRAM. 
 
     ENDCASE. 
 
ENDMODULE. 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*&      Module  READ_DATA  INPUT 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*       text 
*----------------------------------------------------------------------* 
MODULE read_data INPUT. 
modify lt_vbap1 from ls_vbap1 index table2-current_line. 
 
ENDMODULE. 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*&      Module  FIELD-SEL  INPUT 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*       text 
*----------------------------------------------------------------------* 
MODULE field-sel INPUT. 
 
 READ TABLE LT_VBAP INTO LS_VBAP INDEX TABLE1-CURRENT_LINE. 
 IF SY-SUBRC = 0. 
   LS_VBAP1 = LS_VBAP. 
   APPEND LS_VBAP1 TO LT_VBAP1. 
   ENDIF. 
 
ENDMODULE.

entry.title: Untangling the Mess: A Practical Guide to Clean Core Success
entry.content:
Every system is perfectly designed to get the result that it does.  -  W. Edwards Deming.

Background

Do you feel that your system landscape is held together by duct tape and a hope and a prayer?

You are worried that your landscape is meeting today’s needs, but it isn’t ready to adapt to new technologies and face tomorrow’s challenges. As an IT expert, you are not only worried about the sprawl of interconnected (various on-prem and cloud) applications, but you are also worried about poor-quality data and legacy processes. Legacy business processes were designed around the capabilities of applications to such an extent that untangling them seems overwhelming.

How can we get out of this vicious cycle?

Experts often gush out obvious advice like 1) Reduce technical debt, 2) standardize process, and 3) keep data clean, like people maintaining the system don’t already know that. The strategy is clear, but the influence of the status quo is strong, and overcoming this challenge will require time and a cultural shift.

You can follow the SAP Clean Core methodology, but establishing strong governance to implement the obvious advice listed above won’t make a measurable difference in any of these activities.

What is “Core” anyway?

There are five core components that can describe how the business works in the context of an ERP  

  • Business Process: E2E processes describe how the business creates value. Processes are executed by users using applications and by creating/updating/analyzing data. Essentially, these processes facilitate the flow of money, materials, people, and information.
  • Applications and its extensions: Manages processes by applying rules, logic, business flow, preferences and policies.
  • Data: (in various applications): Enterprise structure, Master data, transaction data, unstructured data, etc.
  • Integrations: Connecting internal and external applications where data/information is exchanged
  • Operations: IT operations to manage platforms, upgrades, patches, versions etc.

Figure 1. Interconnected Core and it's key components

 

All these system components work together to ensure that the business functions smoothly. This system is often perfectly designed to achieve the results it does to support today’s business. i.e. "Status quo that works, why change?"  This argument, this complacency, is your number one inhibitor to being ready for tomorrow's opportunities.

Several factors contributed to a complex landscape.

  1. Over the years, as business processes and technology have evolved at different paces, interdependency has continued to increase, resulting in the landscape you see today.
  2. More peripheral applications are being used to complete/automate End-to-End business processes that resulted in multiple integration patterns that link processes, data and applications.
  3. Over the years, various new technologies were implemented through many projects without retrofitting existing applications, which resulted in a sprawl that you see today

Clean Core Principles

The clean core principles help ensure customers’ business-critical systems remain agile, cost-effective, and ready to adopt innovations that drive business forward. By adopting standard processes that incorporate stable extensions and integrations, the clean core principles enable customers to flexibly adapt to changing business requirements and adopt new capabilities.

There are five key clean core principles

Figure 2 - Clean Core Principles

How to implement Clean Core culture?

Defending clean core via governance is an outdated approach. You will need to establish a culture that encourages new behaviour patterns, monitor behaviour systematically and periodically and finally establish strong governance practices.

1. Establish a clean core culture (deter old practices):

  • Everybody wins, or nobody wins. Get your leaders in each domain to acknowledge the interconnectedness of the core components. Create a culture where everyone understands that you are in the same boat; it’s not a responsibility of a single department to maintain the core. Working on one or two components and ignoring others will be futile.
    • How: Leadership, Organization change management, training
  • Showcase what good looks like: Whatever project you are working on, ensure that all project leads, solution experts, and partners own all clean core dimensions (Process, Data, Integration, Extension, and operations). Demonstrating small success early goes a long way. Success breeds success.
    • How: Utilize SAP Signavio (clean core business processes), SAP Extensibility and Integration methodology, etc.
  • Education: Continuous education similar to what we do for “Ethics”, “Security”, etc., is required. Understanding and promoting clean code should be ingrained in the company culture like an honour code.
    • How: SAP learning - Clean Core approach, Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

2 Detect:

Continuously monitor and measure early signs of infractions or a return to old behaviours. Individual infractions should be addressed quickly.

  • Continuous monitoring: Monitor deviations from clean core principles in real-time. The RISE with SAP Dashboard provides all the data you need to take action before it becomes too severe. Information gathered here is based on what’s actually happening in the system. Utilize this information from these tools to find behaviours that are working against clean core principles. e.g. Why are we not seeing an upward trend in the number of APIs being used? Or a reduction in the Level D extension?
    • How: RISE Dashboard in Cloud ALM, ATC Exception
  • Continuous measurement: Measure the maturity of various clean core dimensions, including self-assessment for each dimension. When this is done together for all five dimensions, it fosters healthy debate about interconnectedness, e.g., ‘overly complex business rules result in fragmented processes with redundant extensions and extra integrations.’ Each quarter, measure your score and implement smaller improvements.
    • How: Clean Core KPI assessment

3. Defend:

If you follow the above two steps correctly, the efforts to defend decrease.

  • Governance: This is obvious, but creative consultants always find ways to justify their exceptions. Often, the first exceptions are benign, like a Trojan horse; they start small, and once you are hooked on an exception, you will need to build more complex enhancements and integrations to support your initial move. You will need to have a savvy “consigliere” in the governance body who can see two steps ahead. Often, these governance efforts focus on the project schedule and budget, but the amount of technical debt and process debt incurred during the project often goes unnoticed. We all have heard the phrase “Let’s focus on go-live, we will fix data/process/code later,”; and sadly, later never arrives. In essence, the governance structure must overcome the legacy block of focusing solely on schedule and cost to remain relevant in the clean core era.
    • How: Implement the Solution Standardization Board (SSB) or equivalent with the folks who can see through technical debt and process debt that tries to sneak in
  • Incentives/Penalties: Utilize a clean core scorecard to approve future funding, initiatives, and projects. Providing incentives (funding) for process standardization and penalties (budget control) for enhancement often works.
    • How: Clean core measurements, Portfolio Management. Outcome management, Value Management

Conclusion

Over the years, as business processes and technology have evolved at different paces, interdependency has continued to increase, resulting in the (process, application, data, technology) landscape you see today. This is all managed by a small group that will resist all changes, not because they don’t want to change, but more often because they understand the fragility of the current architecture and how precarious, rushed transformations can be.

Deter, Detect and Defend mindset can help an organization implement clean core principles during a transformation project. This approach provides a fighting chance that the clean core mindset will survive beyond the current focused project. The organization needs to ensure that the “clean core” light is shining bright and there are no dark corners where one-off processes/customization are being worked on.

Complacency with the 'status quo' is not an option. Left unattended, system complexity will continue to grow. The best way to start a clean core journey was 20 years ago; the second best time is today!

Additional References:

  1. Clean core extensibility White paper
  2. Extend SAP S/4HANA in the cloud and on premise with ABAP based extensions
  3. Learning journey “Acquiring Core ABAP Skills”
  4. Learning journey “Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  5. Learning journey “Practicing Clean Core Extensibility For SAP S/4HANA Cloud”
  6. SAP Business Accelerator Hub

entry.title: Re: APP run proposal error
entry.content:
Hello @MdDilshad_Khan67 ,

I could think of below possibilities. Please verify.

 

CauseSymptomsWhere to CheckSolution
1. Errors in ProposalProposal released but no green lightF110 → Edit → Proposal → Proposal LogFix errors (payment block, missing bank details, no open items, payment method missing), then regenerate proposal
2. “Start Immediately” not selectedProposal job stuck in released statusF110 → Proposal tabTick Start Immediately and rerun proposal
3. Background Job stuck or cancelledProposal not processedSM37 → Job F110*If cancelled → fix issue & rerun; If stuck → execute again
4. Old proposal existsSystem reuses old proposal, not generating newF110 → Edit → ProposalDelete existing proposal, then create new proposal
5. Wrong Run Date / Identification IDSystem shows proposal released but cannot continueF110 → Run Date / IdentificationChange Run Date or Identification and rerun proposal
6. Payment block on vendor/invoiceNo items selected for paymentFB03 / FBL1NRemove payment block (FB02) if business allows
7. Missing payment method in Vendor MasterVendor excluded from proposalFK02 → Company Code data → Payment TransactionsAssign correct payment method
8. Missing House Bank / Payment Method ConfigProposal generated with warnings but no payment run possibleOBVCU / FBZPMaintain payment method in FBZP & house bank details
9. No open items fall within parametersProposal says released but nothing selectedF110 → Display ProposalAdjust parameters (posting date, due date, company code, payment method)

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Best practice on Performance Forms for employees who...
entry.content:
Hello! Also not sure about best practice, but sharing another option to consider like Joanne.  When employees enter their new goals, we ask them to indicate which ones are for Role 1 and Role 2 (it's a special field with picklist options) for each goal. And, we ask that they weight the goals so they approximately equal the amount of time they have spent in each role. For example, if they were in Role 1 from Jan - May, they were there for about five months (aka 42% of the year) and in Role 2 from Jun - Dec, they were there for about seven months (58% of the year). So, they could round to have the goals weighted from Role 1 equal 40% and Role 2 equal 60%. 

Then at the end of the year (December) we launch the year-end review form that captures those details  and any comments they've added throughout the year. When they complete their self assessment it goes to their current manager who could then click on the "Get Feedback" button to send it to the previous manager or any other manager that may have had a dotted line to the employee throughout the year so that they can enter their feedback. When that former manager has added comments they send it back to the new manager who can complete the form.

entry.title: Re: Configuring the Internal Hiring/Crossboarding Process in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
