entry.title: Re: MB5L
entry.content:
Hello @tarek07 ,

Try below fixes and let me know if it works.

SectionDetails (Full Content, Not Summarized)
Root CauseMB5L exports numbers using SAP decimal notation, while Excel interprets them using Windows regional settings. If SAP displays 2.000 but Excel expects 2,000 or vice-versa, Excel either drops decimals (2.000 → 2) or multiplies by 1000 (2.000 → 2000). This mismatch leads to inconsistent quantities and values in the spreadsheet after export.
Symptoms in ExcelSAP Value → Excel Result → Problem:• 2.000 → 2 → Excel interprets “.000” as decimals• 2.000 → 2000 → Excel treats “.” as thousand separator• 1.234,56 → 1234.56 → Excel auto-converts locale format• Quantities vary per material → Mixed locale interpretations
Fix 1 – Align SAP decimal notation with Windows/ExcelIn SAP: t-code SU3 → Defaults → Decimal Notation. Set the format to match Windows regional setting:• 1,234.56 (US/UK)• 1.234,56 (EU, LATAM)Re-run MB5L → export again → Excel now reads numbers correctly without modification.
Fix 2 – Export as TXT and import via Excel (controlled import)Steps:1. In MB5L → Export → Local File → TXT2. In Excel → Data → From Text/CSV → Choose file3. Set Column Data Type = Text or Number properly. This prevents Excel from automatically changing decimal/thousand separators and preserves the exact SAP values.
Fix 3 – Uniform formatting in SAP ALV GridIn the MB5L display: Go to Settings → Format → Uniform Formatting. This forces SAP to output consistent, locale-neutral numeric formats when exporting, reducing misinterpretation by Excel.
Fix 4 – Force Excel to treat columns as text before openingBefore opening the file:• Format relevant Excel columns as Text OR• Use Excel: Data → Get Data → From Text/CSV (never double-click the file)<br. This prevents Excel from auto-converting 2.000 into 2 or 2000.
Best Practices for Accurate Exports• Ensure SAP decimal notation = Windows number format (must match exactly).• Prefer exporting as TXT, not XLS, for controlled import.• Always use Data → From Text/CSV to import.• In ALV grid, enable Uniform Format before exporting.• After import, cross-check at least one material’s quantity/value with SAP.
Quick Diagnostic TestCopy the value 2.000 from SAP and paste into Excel:• If Excel shows 2, the decimal notation mismatch is confirmed.• If Excel shows 2000, the thousand separator mismatch is confirmed.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Internal Career Job Posting Search for Location
entry.content:
We have been using the Recruiting module for years and just started using EC earlier this year. Ever since the implementation of EC (including position management) the search functionality for location has not worked on the internal careers site. The jobs don't display the location either, so it's really difficult for employees to find jobs to apply to that are at their location. 

Our tech support have told us that it pulls in from the Department field (position management), which is for the manager's org unit only and that we need to start populating the location field there, as well as create (and maintain) a custom business rule to map the postal code for each location, so that the jobs can be searched on the internal careers site. 

We have a couple of concerns with this approach.

  • First, we want it to display the location of the job requisition/position instead of the manager's Department. Sometimes managers who sit in one location have employees from various locations reporting to them and they want to recruit for a job at a specific location that is different than their own.
  • Second, this would be a lot more maintenance for our HR team to maintain a new field on the Department object, as well as our IT team would need to maintain the business rule each time a new location is added. 

Plus, it just seems odd that it would pull from the manager's Department instead of from the job requisition itself. 

Do you have any suggestions on how we can allow employees to search for jobs by location on the internal careers site?

Thanks!

entry.title: SAP EWM Labor Management (Engineered Labor Standards)
entry.content:
SAP EWM Labor Management is designed to help warehouses gain clear visibility into how efficiently work is performed on the floor. It enables businesses to define labor standards, track planned versus actual execution times, and measure processor performance for different warehouse activities. These standards can be based on various operational parameters such as weight, quantity, product attributes, or activity type, allowing flexible modeling of real-world scenarios. The functionality also supports tracking of both direct tasks and indirect labor efforts, giving a complete picture of workforce utilization. This blog focuses on demonstrating how engineering labor standards work within SAP EWM.

Configurations

1. Activate BC Sets:

T.code: SCPR20

To enable SAP EWM Labor Management (LM) functionality, SAP provides several LM-specific BC Sets. These BC Sets deliver predefined configuration content that supports various LM capabilities such as activity definitions, engineered labor standards, exception codes, performance measurement, and warehouse-level settings.

  • /SCWM/LM
  • /SCWM/LM_ACTIVITY
  • /SCWM/LM_ELS
  • /SCWM/LM_EXCEPTION_CODES
  • /SCWM/LM_EXTERNAL_PROCESS_STEPS
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_EPD
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_INDIRECT_LABOR_TASK
  • /SCWM/LM_PLAN_AREA
  • /SCWM/LM_PREPROCESSING
  • /SCWM/LM_WHS_NUMBER
  • /SCWM/PRC_LM_10
  • /SCWM/PRC_LM_15

2. Activate Labor Management
Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Activate Labor Management

3. Define External Process steps

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define External Process Steps

 

4. Assign External Process steps to warehouse Activity

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Assign External Process Step to Warehouse Activity

5.   Assign Planned Activity Areas

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Assign Planning Activity Areas

6. Define Number Range for Performance Document

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define Number Range for Performance Document

7. Define Delivery Date/Time for Preprocessing

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define Delivery Date/Time for Preprocessing

8. Activate Change Documents in Labor Management

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Activate Change Documents in Labor Management

  • Activate Change Documents for Processor

  • Activate Change Documents for Performance Document

  • Activate Change Documents for Time and Attendance

9. Define Processor Types

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Processor Types

10. Define Reporting Groups for Processors

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Reporting Groups for Processors

11. Define Work Categories

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Work Categories

12. Define Capacity Variants

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Shift Management -> Define Capacity Variants

13. Maintain Shift Management Defaults

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Shift Management -> Maintain Shift Management Defaults



14. Create a Processor

T.Code: /N/SCMB/PRR1

15. Assign User to BP created

16. Conditions for Engineered Labor Standards

T.code: /N/SCWM/LM_CE

17. Formula for Engineered Labor Standards

18. Determine Engineering Labor Standards

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Determine Engineered Labor Standards

Test :

Pre- requisites:
Create two deliveries and distribute them to EWM, ensuring each delivery has a different weight, one below 20 kg and one above 20 kg, to match the conditions we configured.

Let’s first take an example with a weight below 20 kg, execute it, and review the workload. After that, we’ll do the same for a case above 20 kg.

Maintain Inbound Deliveries

T.code: /N/SCWM/PRDI

As you can see, the delivery mentioned above includes a handling unit weighing 4.400 kg. Let’s create the warehouse task for unloading and execute it through the RF screen to validate the processor’s performance.

Let’s create a warehouse Task using Monitor-

T.code: /N/SCWM/PRDI>> Inbound Delivery>>Follow on Functions>>Warehouse Task

By clicking “Create,” the system generates a warehouse task to move the handling unit from the Door to the GR-ZONE (staging area). Next, let’s review the Warehouse Order for “LM Active.” As shown, the LM Active checkbox is enabled, indicating that Labor Management is activated for this step.

Now let’s execute the activity in RF screen
Path: Inbound>> Unloading>> Unload by Delivery

Upon scanning the HU, the system captures the start timestamp and initiates the timer to measure the total time taken by the associate or processor to complete the activity.

Once you scan the destination bin and confirm “Yes” for Completely Unloaded, the timer stops. Now let’s review the workload in the monitor.

The screenshot above is from the workload monitor, which displays the execution details. As shown, the processor “NICK WILDE” executed the unloading task, with the recorded weight of 4.2 kg. The planned execution time is 5 minutes, which is a critical value derived from the condition and formula maintained in configuration steps 16 and 17.

The monitor also shows the actual execution details start and end timestamps, planned duration, and the actual duration taken by the processor. In this example, the processor took 7.467 minutes to complete the task, compared to the planned 5 minutes. Based on this variance, the system calculated the processor’s efficiency as 66.96%.

Now, let’s take another delivery with a weight of 42.200 kg and review how the system determines the planned execution time for unloading, using the same configuration rules from steps 16 and 17.

Let’s execute the step and find out the performance

After execution, the planned time is 7 minutes, calculated based on the configured formula. The actual duration recorded is 18.317 minutes, resulting in an efficiency of 38.22%, since the processor took significantly longer than the planned time.

Through these scenarios, we validated how SAP EWM Labor Management calculates planned, actual, and efficient metrics using condition-based formulas. By executing unloading tasks for deliveries below and above the 20 kg threshold, we observed how the system dynamically derives planned execution time and evaluates processor performance via RF-driven timestamps. Importantly, these calculations are not limited to weight alone any relevant operational parameter (such as quantity, HU type, product group, packaging material, distance, activity type, or process step) can be incorporated into the condition and formula framework.

This flexibility allows organizations to tailor labor standards to real-world warehouse processes. Overall, these examples demonstrate how workload monitoring offers clear visibility into performance, highlights gaps between planned and actual durations, and enables data-driven optimization of warehouse efficiency in SAP EWM.

entry.title: Re: Copy functionality in AFC
entry.content:
Hello @JFPC ,

Try below options.

 

TopicFull Details (Not Summarized)
Short AnswerYES — you can reuse your AFC closing template from Test for Production. NO — you do not redo everything manually. Templates are NOT transported using SAP transports. Instead, AFC provides built-in “Export / Import” functions for templates, task lists, calendars, and configuration.
How AFC WorksAFC is not transported via SAP transports (like customizing). It is a standalone cloud tenant that connects to multiple backend systems (Test, Dev, Prod). Templates live in the AFC tenant. Backend S/4 systems are only used to execute tasks. Templates are not dependent on a specific S/4 system. You can import → validate → activate templates per connected system. This is why copy/export/import tools exist.
Option 1: Export / Import Template (Recommended)In Test System: 1) Go to Closing Structure → Templates, 2) Select the template, 3) Export Template (generates a JSON file). In Production System: 1) Go to Closing Structure → Templates, 2) Choose Import Template, 3) Upload the exported file, 4) Reassign company codes, systems, scheduling rules, and variants as needed. This is SAP’s recommended method.
Option 2: Duplicate Template Inside AFC and Change System AssignmentSteps: 1) In AFC, go to Templates, 2) Choose Copy / Duplicate, 3) Change System Assignment from TEST → PRD, 4) Revalidate task dependencies. Works if you have the same org structure, same task library, and same company codes in PROD.
Option 3: Use AFC Content LifecycleIf AFC version supports it (2023+ features), use Content Lifecycle Management to move templates, task lists, variants, schedules, orchestrations. This is the enterprise-grade approach for customers with large AFC environments.
What Does NOT Work❌ Transporting configuration via STMS or customizing transports. ❌ Copying directly inside S/4. ❌ Re-creating tasks manually in PROD without AFC import. ❌ Migration Cockpit (irrelevant for AFC). AFC templates live in AFC tenant and are moved via AFC tools only.
What Needs Adjustment After ImportAfter importing the template into PROD, you must check or adjust: company codes (mapping Test → Prod), factory calendars (Prod may differ), task scheduling offsets (if Prod closing calendar is different), user assignments (Prod users differ), authorizations for executors. Structure is identical, but assignments require validation.
Final RecommendationBuild and test the template in Test. Export it when Test is approved. Import into Production once the system is connected. Validate tasks → Generate closing task list → Activate. This prevents days of rework and ensures consistent closing processes across Test and Production.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh
